attribute-processor.name: alt-title
attribute-processor.documentation: Sets both the alt and title attributes.

attribute-processor.name: attr

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section 5 on Setting Attribute Values

attribute-processor.documentation:
Sets the value of any attribute/s. Takes a list of comma-separated attribute/expression pairs, eg:

<img src="../../images/gtvglogo.png" th:attr="src=@{/images/gtvglogo.png},title=#{logo},alt=#{logo}" />

The above will set the src, title, and alt attributes to the results of each of their respective expressions.

attribute-processor.name: attrappend

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section 5.4 on Appending And Prepending

attribute-processor.documentation:
Appends the result of an expression to any attribute/s, eg:

<input type="button" value="Do it!" class="btn" th:attrappend="class=${' ' + cssStyle}" />

If you process this template with the cssStyle variable set to "warning", you will get:

<input type="button" value="Do it!" class="btn warning" />

attribute-processor.name: attrprepend

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section 5.4 on Appending And Prepending

attribute-processor.documentation:
Prepends the result of an expression to any attribute/s, eg:

<input type="button" value="Do it!" class="btn" th:attrappend="class=${cssStyle + ' '}" />

If you process this template with the cssStyle variable set to "warning", you will get:

<input type="button" value="Do it!" class="warning btn" />

attribute-processor.name: case

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section 7.2 on Switch Statements

attribute-processor.documentation: Used together with the th:switch attribute processor, identifies an element to be rendered if its expression matches the result of the th:switch expression.

attribute-processor.name: classappend

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section 5.4 on Appending And Prepending

attribute-processor.documentation:
Appends the result of an expression to the class attribute, eg:

<div class="item" th:classappend="${myObject.type == 'special'} ? 'special' : 'normal'" />

Depending on the result of the expression, the class attribute will become either "item special" or "item normal".

attribute-processor.name: each

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section 6.2 on Keeping Iteration Status

attribute-processor.documentation:
Iterates through a collection of objects, repeating each of the child elements for every object in that collection, eg:

<tr th:each="prod : ${prods}">
  <td th:text="${prod.name}">Product name</td>
  <td th:text="${prod.price}">Product price</td>
</tr>

That "prod : ${prods}" attribute value you see above means "for each element in the result of evaluating ${prods}, repeat this fragment of template setting that element into a variable called prod".

A collection can be any java.util.Iterable, a java.util.Map (iteration variables will be a java.util.Map.Entry), or an array.

attribute-processor.name: fragment

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section 8.1 on Including Template Fragments

attribute-processor.documentation: Gives a name to sections of your template that are available for inclusion by the th:include and th:substituteby processors.

attribute-processor.name: object

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section 4.3 on the asterisk syntax

attribute-processor.documentation:
Selects an object so that its methods and properties can be accessed using the shortcut *{...} syntax, eg:

<div th:object="${session.user}">
  <span th:text="*{firstName}">First name</span>
  <span th:text="*{lastName}">Last name</span>
</div>

attribute-processor.name: if

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section 7.1 on Simple Conditionals

attribute-processor.documentation: Evaluates an expression that, if true, will cause this element and it's children to be rendered. If the expression is false, then this element and it's children will be removed.

attribute-processor.name: inline
attribute-processor.documentation:
Lets you use expressions directly in your template.

If this attribute's value is text, then you can use the [[...]] syntax to put expressions within your text without having to use the th:text attribute processor, eg:
<p th:inline="text">Hello [[${session.user.name}]]!<p>

If this attribute's value is javascript or dart, and used in a <script> tag, then you can insert expressions directly into your JavaScript/Dart code with the /*[[...]]*/, /*[+...+]*/, and /*[-...-]*/ syntaxes.

attribute-processor.name: unless

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section 7.1 on Simple Conditionals

attribute-processor.documentation: The opposite of th:if, evaluates an expression that, if false, will cause this element and it's children to be rendered.

attribute-processor.name: include

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section 8.1 on Including Template Fragments

attribute-processor.documentation:
Specifies another template and the fragment within that other template to include at this point, eg:

<div th:include="templateName :: fragmentName"><div>

The above will find the template named templateName, and add the fragment named fragmentName as a child of this element.

attribute-processor.name: lang-xmllang
attribute-processor.documentation: Sets both the lang and xml:lang attributes.

attribute-processor.name: remove

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section 8.2 on Removing Template Fragments

attribute-processor.documentation:
Removes a piece of this template from the final result.

If this attribute's value is all, both the containing tag and it's children will be removed. If the value is body, only the tag's children will be removed. If the value is tag, the containing tag will be removed, but not it's children. If the value is all-but-first, then all but the first child of the containing tag will be removed.

attribute-processor.name: substituteby

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section 8.1 on Including Template Fragments

attribute-processor.documentation: Similar to th:include, but instead of adding the specified template fragment as a child of this element, it will replace this element with the template fragment.

attribute-processor.name: switch

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section section 7.2 on Switch Statements

attribute-processor.documentation:
Selects a child element for rendering if the child's th:case expression is an exact match of this processor's expression, eg:

<div th:switch="${user.role}">
  <p th:case="'admin'">User is an administrator</p>
  <p th:case="#{roles.manager}">User is a manager</p>
</div>

Note that as soon as one th:case attribute is evaluated as true, every other th:case attribute in the same switch context is evaluated as false.
The default option is specified as th:case="*"

attribute-processor.name: text

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section 3 on Using Texts

attribute-processor.documentation: Replaces the text content of this tag with the result of an expression. Performs escaping of any special characters so that the text is valid HTML/XML text.

attribute-processor.name: utext

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section 3.2 on Unescaped Text

attribute-processor.documentation: Does the same as th:text except that it doesn't perform any escaping of special characters. Useful if the replacement text has HTML/XML characters that you want added to the rendered page.

attribute-processor.name: with

documentation.reference: Using Thymeleaf section 9 on Local Variables

attribute-processor.documentation:
Create one or more local variables scoped to this tag, that can then be referred to by other expressions. Takes a comma-separated list of localname/expression pairs, eg:

<div th:with="firstPer=${persons[0]},secondPer=${persons[1]}">
  <p th:text="${firstPer.name}">First person name<p>
  <p th:text="${secondPer.name}">Second person name<p>
</div>

attribute-processor.name: xmlbase
attribute-processor.documentation: Sets the xml:base attribute to the result of the expression.

attribute-processor.name: xmllang
attribute-processor.documentation: Sets the xml:lang attribute to the result of the expression.

attribute-processor.name: xmlspace
attribute-processor.documentation: Sets the xml:space attribute to the result of the expression.

attribute-processor.name: alt
attribute-processor.documentation: Sets the alt attribute to the result of the expression.

attribute-processor.name: lang
attribute-processor.documentation: Sets the lang attribute to the result of the expression.

attribute-processor.name: title
attribute-processor.documentation: Sets the title attribute to the result of the expression.
